content.passage: Read the following sentence: The management team, after reviewing the quarterly reports, [CHOICE] ready to announce its decision.
content.questionText: Select the verb that correctly completes the sentence.

answerOptions.text: is
answerOptions.rationale: The subject 'team' is a collective noun acting as a single unit, so it takes the singular verb 'is'.

answerOptions.text: are
answerOptions.rationale: Even though a team contains many people, here it functions as one body and therefore does not take a plural verb.

answerOptions.text: were
answerOptions.rationale: 'Were' is past tense and plural, so it does not fit the present-tense context.

answerOptions.text: have been
answerOptions.rationale: This plural verb phrase mismatches the singular subject.

content.passage: Choose the verb that completes the sentence: Neither the players nor the coach [CHOICE] willing to postpone the tournament.
content.questionText: Which option correctly completes the sentence?

answerOptions.text: is
answerOptions.rationale: With 'neither...nor,' the verb agrees with the subject closest to it; 'coach' is singular, so use 'is'.

answerOptions.text: are
answerOptions.rationale: 'Are' would agree with 'players,' but the verb must match the nearer subject 'coach'.

answerOptions.text: be
answerOptions.rationale: The base form does not agree with the sentence structure.

answerOptions.text: were
answerOptions.rationale: This plural past-tense verb does not match the present context.

content.passage: Choose the verb that completes the sentence: The boxes of donated books [CHOICE] stacked neatly in the hallway.
content.questionText: Which option correctly completes the sentence?

answerOptions.text: are
answerOptions.rationale: The true subject is 'boxes,' which is plural, requiring the verb 'are'.

answerOptions.text: is
answerOptions.rationale: A singular verb would be used only if the subject were singular.

answerOptions.text: was
answerOptions.rationale: This is past tense and does not match the present tense of the sentence.

answerOptions.text: has been
answerOptions.rationale: This perfect tense construction does not align with the simple present structure.

content.passage: Choose the verb that completes the sentence: Each of the applicants [CHOICE] submitted a portfolio for review.
content.questionText: Which option correctly completes the sentence?

answerOptions.text: has
answerOptions.rationale: 'Each' is singular, so the verb must be singular: 'has'.

answerOptions.text: have
answerOptions.rationale: 'Have' is plural and does not agree with the singular subject 'Each'.

answerOptions.text: were
answerOptions.rationale: This plural past-tense verb does not match the sentence.

answerOptions.text: are
answerOptions.rationale: This plural present-tense verb does not agree with the subject.

content.passage: Choose the verb that completes the sentence: My brother, along with his friends, [CHOICE] planning a surprise party.
content.questionText: Which option correctly completes the sentence?

answerOptions.text: is
answerOptions.rationale: The subject is 'My brother'; the phrase 'along with his friends' is additional information and does not change the singular verb.

answerOptions.text: are
answerOptions.rationale: 'Are' would agree with a plural subject, but the main subject is singular.

answerOptions.text: be
answerOptions.rationale: This form is grammatically incomplete in the sentence.

answerOptions.text: were
answerOptions.rationale: This past-tense plural form does not agree with the present singular subject.

content.passage: Choose the verb that completes the sentence: Either the printers or the fax machine [CHOICE] responsible for the noise in the office.
content.questionText: Which option correctly completes the sentence?

answerOptions.text: is
answerOptions.rationale: With 'either...or,' the verb agrees with the subject nearer to it; 'machine' is singular, so 'is' is required.

answerOptions.text: are
answerOptions.rationale: 'Are' would agree with the plural 'printers,' but the verb must match the nearer subject.

answerOptions.text: were
answerOptions.rationale: This plural past-tense verb does not fit the sentence.

answerOptions.text: have been
answerOptions.rationale: This plural perfect tense does not agree with the singular subject.

content.passage: Choose the verb that completes the sentence: The data from the latest studies [CHOICE] especially promising for future treatments.
content.questionText: Which option correctly completes the sentence?

answerOptions.text: are
answerOptions.rationale: In academic contexts, 'data' is treated as a plural noun, so it pairs with the plural verb 'are'.

answerOptions.text: is
answerOptions.rationale: Using 'is' would treat 'data' as singular, which is not standard in formal writing.

answerOptions.text: was
answerOptions.rationale: This past tense does not match the present-tense description.

answerOptions.text: be
answerOptions.rationale: The base form cannot serve as the main verb here.

content.passage: Choose the verb that completes the sentence: The number of volunteers [CHOICE] increasing every week as the event approaches.
content.questionText: Which option correctly completes the sentence?

answerOptions.text: is
answerOptions.rationale: 'The number' is singular, so the verb must be singular: 'is'.

answerOptions.text: are
answerOptions.rationale: 'Are' would agree with 'volunteers,' but the true subject is the singular phrase 'The number'.

answerOptions.text: have
answerOptions.rationale: This plural verb form does not agree with the subject.

answerOptions.text: were
answerOptions.rationale: This past-tense plural verb does not match the present context.

content.passage: Choose the verb that completes the sentence: A bouquet of roses [CHOICE] waiting on the table when we arrived.
content.questionText: Which option correctly completes the sentence?

answerOptions.text: was
answerOptions.rationale: The subject is the singular noun 'bouquet,' so the singular past-tense verb 'was' is appropriate.

answerOptions.text: were
answerOptions.rationale: 'Were' would be used with a plural subject, but 'bouquet' is singular.

answerOptions.text: are
answerOptions.rationale: This plural present-tense verb does not match the sentence.

answerOptions.text: be
answerOptions.rationale: The infinitive form does not fit grammatically.

content.passage: Choose the verb that completes the sentence: Neither of the solutions [CHOICE] acceptable to the client.
content.questionText: Which option correctly completes the sentence?

answerOptions.text: is
answerOptions.rationale: 'Neither' takes a singular verb, so 'is' is the correct choice.

answerOptions.text: are
answerOptions.rationale: This plural verb does not agree with the singular subject 'Neither'.

answerOptions.text: have been
answerOptions.rationale: This plural verb phrase disagrees with the singular subject.

answerOptions.text: were
answerOptions.rationale: This past-tense plural verb does not match the structure.

content.passage: Choose the verb that completes the sentence: The team of engineers [CHOICE] completing its prototype ahead of schedule.
content.questionText: Which option correctly completes the sentence?

answerOptions.text: is
answerOptions.rationale: The subject 'team' is singular even though it contains many members, so the verb must be 'is'.

answerOptions.text: are
answerOptions.rationale: 'Are' would treat 'team' as plural, which is inconsistent with the collective noun usage here.

answerOptions.text: be
answerOptions.rationale: The base form does not work as the main verb.

answerOptions.text: were
answerOptions.rationale: This plural past-tense verb does not match the sentence.

content.passage: Choose the verb that completes the sentence: Both the manager and the assistants [CHOICE] attending the regional conference this month.
content.questionText: Which option correctly completes the sentence?

answerOptions.text: are
answerOptions.rationale: 'Both...and' creates a plural subject, so the plural verb 'are' is needed.

answerOptions.text: is
answerOptions.rationale: A singular verb would not agree with the compound subject.

answerOptions.text: was
answerOptions.rationale: This past-tense singular verb does not match the present plural subject.

answerOptions.text: has been
answerOptions.rationale: This singular verb phrase still fails to agree with the plural subject.

quizzes.label: Quiz A
quizzes.description: Strengthen grammar, usage, and mechanics skills for the RLA test.

quizzes.label: Quiz B
quizzes.description: Focus on sentence structure, punctuation, and capitalization.

questions.question: Which of the following sentences is capitalized correctly?

answerOptions.text: We visited the Grand Canyon, a famous landmark in arizona.
answerOptions.rationale: The state name 'Arizona' should be capitalized.

answerOptions.text: My favorite book is 'The Catcher In The Rye' by J.D. Salinger.
answerOptions.rationale: In titles, prepositions like 'in' and articles like 'the' are typically not capitalized unless they are the first or last word.

answerOptions.text: She is studying french and european history at the university.
answerOptions.rationale: 'French' and 'European' should be capitalized as they are proper adjectives.

answerOptions.text: The President of the United States will address the nation on Tuesday.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. 'President' is capitalized as a title, and 'Tuesday' is a proper noun.

questions.question: Which sentence uses commas correctly?

answerOptions.text: After a long, and tiring day, we finally went home.
answerOptions.rationale: There should not be a comma after 'long' or 'tiring' if 'and' is used. Also, no comma after 'day'.

answerOptions.text: She packed a sandwich, an apple, and a bottle of water.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This sentence correctly uses the Oxford comma to separate items in a list.

answerOptions.text: He was, however, not ready to leave.
answerOptions.rationale: While commas around 'however' can be correct, the flow here is awkward. A better structure would be 'He was not ready to leave, however.'

answerOptions.text: The man who was wearing a red hat, was my uncle.
answerOptions.rationale: The clause 'who was wearing a red hat' is essential to identify the man, so it should not be set off by commas.

questions.question: Which sentence is punctuated correctly with a semicolon?

answerOptions.text: We planned the fundraiser; and we designed the posters.
answerOptions.rationale: A semicolon should not be used before a coordinating conjunction like 'and'.

answerOptions.text: The meeting ran late; everyone stayed to finish the report.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The semicolon joins two closely related independent clauses.

answerOptions.text: It was raining;, so we canceled the picnic.
answerOptions.rationale: The semicolon and comma together are incorrect.

answerOptions.text: She wanted to join the club; but she missed the deadline.
answerOptions.rationale: A comma should be used with 'but,' not a semicolon.

questions.question: Select the sentence that correctly punctuates a compound sentence.

answerOptions.text: The river flooded the road therefore we stayed home.
answerOptions.rationale: A coordinating conjunction like 'therefore' needs a comma or semicolon before it.

answerOptions.text: The sky darkened, and thunder rolled across the hills.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The comma before 'and' properly joins two independent clauses.

answerOptions.text: The lights flickered and, the television went silent.
answerOptions.rationale: The comma is misplaced.

answerOptions.text: We hurried inside but, the rain had already started.
answerOptions.rationale: The comma should come before 'but,' not after it.

questions.question: Which sentence uses a colon correctly?

answerOptions.text: Her to-do list included: vacuuming the living room, washing the dishes, and folding laundry.
answerOptions.rationale: A colon should not come directly after a verb unless the list is formally introduced.

answerOptions.text: There are three things I love about autumn: crisp air, colorful leaves, and warm cider.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The independent clause before the colon introduces the list clearly.

answerOptions.text: He said: that he would arrive late.
answerOptions.rationale: The colon interrupts the flow of the sentence unnecessarily.

answerOptions.text: Please bring: your ID and ticket to the event.
answerOptions.rationale: A colon is not needed between the verb and its objects.

questions.question: Which option shows the correct use of a hyphen?

answerOptions.text: We saw a well known author at the bookstore.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Well-known' should be hyphenated before a noun.

answerOptions.text: The twenty-four-year-old pianist won the competition.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. All parts of a compound adjective before a noun are hyphenated.

answerOptions.text: Please re-elect the vice president tomorrow.
answerOptions.rationale: A hyphen is not needed in 're-elect' in modern usage.

answerOptions.text: Our plan is cost-effective because we cut unnecessary expenses.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Cost-effective' should be hyphenated when used before or after a noun, but this option is missing the hyphen.

questions.question: Which sentence uses apostrophes correctly?

answerOptions.text: The womens' locker room was recently renovated.
answerOptions.rationale: The plural possessive of 'women' is 'women's.'

answerOptions.text: James's guitar needs to be tuned before the show.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Singular nouns ending in s typically add 's to show possession.

answerOptions.text: Its' wheels squeaked as it rolled down the hallway.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Its' is already possessive; no apostrophe is needed.

answerOptions.text: The dogs collar jingled as she ran.
answerOptions.rationale: The possessive form should be 'dog's'.

questions.question: Which sentence maintains parallel structure?

answerOptions.text: The campers enjoy hiking, to swim, and sitting by the fire.
answerOptions.rationale: The verbs are not in the same form.

answerOptions.text: The internship requires attention to detail, communicating clearly, and that you arrive on time.
answerOptions.rationale: The third element does not match the structure of the first two.

answerOptions.text: He promised to proofread the report, to email the client, and to schedule the follow-up meeting.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Each phrase begins with 'to,' creating a parallel structure.

answerOptions.text: She likes reading novels, to paint landscapes, and baking bread.
answerOptions.rationale: The verb forms are inconsistent.

questions.question: Which sentence punctuates dialogue correctly?

answerOptions.text: "Let's head inside", whispered Leo.
answerOptions.rationale: The period should be inside the quotation marks, and the dialogue tag should follow after a comma.

answerOptions.text: "Are you ready for the quiz?" asked Ms. Patel.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The question mark stays inside the quotation marks, and the tag follows.

answerOptions.text: "I can't believe it!", she said.
answerOptions.rationale: The punctuation is out of order and excessive.

answerOptions.text: He replied, "I think so?"
answerOptions.rationale: The punctuation after the quote is incorrect.

questions.question: Which revision correctly fixes the run-on sentence? 'The choir rehearsed for hours it wanted the concert to be perfect.'

answerOptions.text: The choir rehearsed for hours wanting the concert to be perfect.
answerOptions.rationale: This still creates a run-on by joining ideas without proper punctuation.

answerOptions.text: The choir rehearsed for hours, it wanted the concert to be perfect.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a comma splice.

answerOptions.text: The choir rehearsed for hours because it wanted the concert to be perfect.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Adding a subordinating conjunction creates a complete complex sentence.

answerOptions.text: The choir rehearsed for hours; wanting the concert to be perfect.
answerOptions.rationale: The clause after the semicolon is not independent.

questions.question: Which sentence uses an em dash appropriately?

answerOptions.text: The recipe called for three ingredients—flour, sugar, butter—and eggs.
answerOptions.rationale: The sentence uses both a dash and 'and' redundantly.

answerOptions.text: Only one person—Jamal—volunteered to stay late and clean up.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The em dashes set off an interruption that adds emphasis.

answerOptions.text: She packed her bag—, then she left for the airport.
answerOptions.rationale: The dash and comma together are incorrect.

answerOptions.text: We will—we must—finish the project tomorrow?,
answerOptions.rationale: The punctuation at the end is incorrect.

questions.question: Which sentence avoids unnecessary wordiness?

answerOptions.text: Due to the fact that the train was late, we arrived behind schedule.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Due to the fact that' is wordy; 'Because' would be clearer.

answerOptions.text: Because the train was late, we arrived behind schedule.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The sentence is concise and clear.

answerOptions.text: On account of the train having been late in its arrival, we were delayed.
answerOptions.rationale: This sentence is wordy and awkward.

answerOptions.text: We were delayed for the reason that the train was late in arriving.
answerOptions.rationale: This sentence is repetitive and wordy.

quizzes.label: Quiz C
quizzes.description: Master verb tenses, subject-verb agreement, and pronoun usage.

questions.question: Which sentence demonstrates correct subject-verb agreement?

answerOptions.text: The team of players are ready for the game.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Team' is a singular noun, so the verb should be 'is'.

answerOptions.text: Each of the boys has his own ticket.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. 'Each' is a singular pronoun, so it takes the singular verb 'has'.

answerOptions.text: The news about the storms were frightening.
answerOptions.rationale: 'News' is a singular noun, so the verb should be 'was'.

answerOptions.text: There is three reasons for the delay.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Reasons' is plural, so the verb should be 'are'.

questions.question: Choose the sentence that uses pronouns correctly.

answerOptions.text: Her and her friends went to the movies.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Her' is an object pronoun and cannot be the subject of a sentence. It should be 'She'.

answerOptions.text: The teacher gave the award to John and I.
answerOptions.rationale: 'I' is a subject pronoun. The object of the preposition 'to' should be 'me'.

answerOptions.text: Just between you and me, I think the plan will fail.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. 'Me' is the correct object pronoun to use after the preposition 'between'.

answerOptions.text: Everyone must turn in their assignment by Friday.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a common usage, but traditionally 'everyone' is singular and should be paired with 'his or her'. However, 'their' is increasingly accepted. In a strict grammar context, it's often considered incorrect.

questions.question: Which sentence maintains consistent verb tense?

answerOptions.text: Maria finished her homework and goes outside to play.
answerOptions.rationale: The verbs shift from past to present without reason.

answerOptions.text: The orchestra tunes their instruments and then performed the piece.
answerOptions.rationale: The verbs shift from present to past unnecessarily.

answerOptions.text: After they packed the car, they drove to the campsite.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Both verbs are in the past tense and logically ordered.

answerOptions.text: He will studies the notes before the exam.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Will studies' is not a correct verb form.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the correct pronoun in a compound object?

answerOptions.text: The invitation was addressed to Carlos and I.
answerOptions.rationale: 'I' should be 'me' as part of the object of the preposition 'to'.

answerOptions.text: Grandma baked cookies for my sister and me.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. 'Me' is the appropriate object pronoun.

answerOptions.text: The coach congratulated she and I after the game.
answerOptions.rationale: Both pronouns should be in object form: 'her and me'.

answerOptions.text: Our neighbors invited we to their barbecue.
answerOptions.rationale: 'We' should be 'us'.

questions.question: Which sentence forms the comparative adjective correctly?

answerOptions.text: This puzzle is more easier than the last one.
answerOptions.rationale: 'More' and '-er' should not be used together.

answerOptions.text: Of the two routes, the highway is faster.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. 'Faster' is the proper comparative form when comparing two items.

answerOptions.text: This recipe is gooder than the other one.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Gooder' is not a standard comparative form.

answerOptions.text: Our team played most well in the second half.
answerOptions.rationale: The comparative form should be 'better'.

questions.question: Which sentence places the modifier correctly?

answerOptions.text: Running down the street, the backpack fell off Jamal's shoulder.
answerOptions.rationale: It sounds like the backpack was running.

answerOptions.text: She nearly drove her brother to school every day.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Nearly drove' changes the meaning.

answerOptions.text: Walking into the auditorium, Maya spotted her friends in the front row.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The introductory modifier clearly refers to Maya.

answerOptions.text: After finishing the experiment, the results were recorded by the students.
answerOptions.rationale: The modifier should clearly reference the students, not the results.

questions.question: Which option correctly uses the past perfect tense?

answerOptions.text: By the time we arrived, the movie started.
answerOptions.rationale: The past perfect is needed to show which action happened first.

answerOptions.text: They had eaten dinner before the guests knocked on the door.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. 'Had eaten' shows the meal was finished before the knock.

answerOptions.text: When the bell had rung, students leave the classroom.
answerOptions.rationale: Tense inconsistency makes the sentence incorrect.

answerOptions.text: She had goes to the store before it closed.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Had goes' is not a correct verb form.

questions.question: Which sentence uses 'who' or 'whom' correctly?

answerOptions.text: To who should I address the letter?
answerOptions.rationale: 'Whom' is needed as the object of the preposition 'to'.

answerOptions.text: Whom is making the announcement this afternoon?
answerOptions.rationale: 'Who' should be used as the subject of the sentence.

answerOptions.text: We asked whom the scholarship committee selected.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. 'Whom' functions as the object of 'selected'.

answerOptions.text: The neighbors, who we admire, are moving next week.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Whom' should be used because it is the object of 'admire'.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the correct pronoun to agree with its antecedent?

answerOptions.text: Neither of the singers forgot their lyrics.
answerOptions.rationale: A singular pronoun should refer back to 'neither'.

answerOptions.text: Each student must bring their own calculator.
answerOptions.rationale: In traditional grammar rules, 'each' is singular and should pair with 'his or her'.

answerOptions.text: Anyone who wants a program should pick up his or her copy at the door.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. 'Anyone' is singular, so 'his or her' maintains agreement.

answerOptions.text: Everybody need to turn in their assignments.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Everybody' is singular and should take 'needs'.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the correct form of the verb with an indefinite pronoun?

answerOptions.text: All of the pie was eaten by the guests.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. 'All' refers to a singular noun ('pie'), so the singular verb 'was' is appropriate.

answerOptions.text: None of the cookies is missing from the plate.
answerOptions.rationale: 'None' with a plural noun typically takes a plural verb: 'are missing'.

answerOptions.text: Some of the students has finished the project.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Some' with a plural noun should take 'have'.

answerOptions.text: Most of the water have evaporated.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Water' is singular, so the verb should be 'has'.

questions.question: Which sentence correctly distinguishes between 'its' and 'it's'?

answerOptions.text: The company updated it's website after the launch.
answerOptions.rationale: 'It's' means 'it is' and is incorrect here.

answerOptions.text: The cat stretched its paws before curling up on the blanket.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. 'Its' shows possession without an apostrophe.

answerOptions.text: Its going to rain later this evening.
answerOptions.rationale: 'It's' (it is) should be used here.

answerOptions.text: The tree lost it's leaves early this year.
answerOptions.rationale: The possessive pronoun should be 'its'.

questions.question: Which sentence avoids a double negative?

answerOptions.text: I can't hardly hear the speaker from the back row.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Can't hardly' creates a double negative.

answerOptions.text: We didn't see no shooting stars last night.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Didn't' and 'no' create a double negative.

answerOptions.text: The librarian didn't tell anyone to remain quiet.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Only one negative word is used.

answerOptions.text: He hasn't never tried sushi before.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Hasn't never' is a double negative.

questions.question: Which of the following sentences is grammatically correct?

answerOptions.text: Her and her friend went to the store.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Her' is an object pronoun and cannot be the subject. The correct pronoun is 'She'.

answerOptions.text: The dog wagged it's tail happily.
answerOptions.rationale: 'It's' is a contraction for 'it is'. The possessive form is 'its'.

answerOptions.text: Each of the students has a pencil.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The subject 'Each' is singular and correctly pairs with the singular verb 'has'.

answerOptions.text: There is too many people in this room.
answerOptions.rationale: 'People' is plural, so the verb should be 'are', not 'is'.

questions.question: Which sentence is punctuated correctly?

answerOptions.text: We went to the park, it was a beautiful day.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a comma splice, where two independent clauses are joined only by a comma.

answerOptions.text: Because it was a beautiful day we went to the park.
answerOptions.rationale: An introductory clause like this should be followed by a comma.

answerOptions.text: It was a beautiful day, so we went to the park.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. A comma is used before the coordinating conjunction 'so' to connect two independent clauses.

answerOptions.text: It was a beautiful day and we went to the park.
answerOptions.rationale: A semicolon should not be used with a coordinating conjunction like 'and'.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the correct form of the verb?

answerOptions.text: Yesterday, I seen the movie you recommended.
answerOptions.rationale: The correct past tense of 'see' is 'saw'. 'Seen' is the past participle.

answerOptions.text: She has went to the library every day this week.
answerOptions.rationale: The past participle of 'go' is 'gone', not 'went'. It should be 'has gone'.

answerOptions.text: He had already eaten when we arrived.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This sentence correctly uses the past perfect tense ('had eaten') to describe an action completed before another past action.

answerOptions.text: They was happy with the results.
answerOptions.rationale: The subject 'They' is plural, so the verb should be 'were', not 'was'.

questions.question: Which of the following sentences is structured most clearly?

answerOptions.text: Running through the park, the dog chased the ball.
answerOptions.rationale: This sentence is clear, but the introductory phrase could be slightly ambiguous.

answerOptions.text: The dog chased the ball, running through the park.
answerOptions.rationale: The placement of the final phrase is slightly awkward.

answerOptions.text: While running through the park, the dog chased the ball.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The introductory phrase 'While running through the park' clearly modifies the dog's action, making the sentence structure logical and unambiguous.

answerOptions.text: The ball was chased by the dog running through the park.
answerOptions.rationale: The passive voice makes this sentence less direct and clear than the active voice alternatives.

questions.question: Which sentence correctly uses a semicolon?

answerOptions.text: I have a big test tomorrow I can't go out tonight.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The semicolon joins two closely related independent clauses.

answerOptions.text: When I get home I will call you.
answerOptions.rationale: A semicolon should not be used to separate a dependent clause from an independent clause.

answerOptions.text: The ingredients are flour, sugar, and eggs.
answerOptions.rationale: A semicolon should not be used to introduce a list.

answerOptions.text: He was tired but he kept working.
answerOptions.rationale: A comma, not a semicolon, should be used before a coordinating conjunction like 'but'.

questions.question: Which sentence correctly uses the pronoun 'who' or 'whom'?

answerOptions.text: Whom is at the door?
answerOptions.rationale: 'Who' should be used as the subject of the verb 'is'.

answerOptions.text: The person whom I spoke with was very helpful.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. 'Whom' is the correct choice as the object of the preposition 'with'.

answerOptions.text: She is the one whom, I believe, deserves the award.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Who' is the subject of 'deserves', so 'who' is the correct choice.

answerOptions.text: Who did you give the package to?
answerOptions.rationale: 'Whom' is the object of the preposition 'to', so 'whom' is the grammatically correct choice, although 'who' is common in informal speech.

questions.question: Which sentence avoids a dangling modifier?

answerOptions.text: After finishing my homework, the TV was turned on.
answerOptions.rationale: This sentence implies the TV finished the homework. The modifier 'After finishing my homework' is dangling.

answerOptions.text: Walking to the store, the rain began to fall.
answerOptions.rationale: This implies the rain was walking to the store. The modifier is dangling.

answerOptions.text: To improve his grade, extra credit was completed.
answerOptions.rationale: This implies the extra credit wanted to improve its grade. The modifier is dangling.

answerOptions.text: While I was washing the dishes, I heard a loud noise outside.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The subject of the introductory clause ('I') is the same as the subject of the main clause, so the modifier is not dangling.

questions.question: Which of the following represents the clearest and most concise way to phrase the sentence?

answerOptions.text: The reason why he was late was due to the fact that his car broke down.
answerOptions.rationale: This sentence is redundant ('reason why', 'due to the fact that').

answerOptions.text: He was late because his car broke down.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This sentence is direct, concise, and clearly states the cause and effect.

answerOptions.text: His lateness was a result of his car having broken down.
answerOptions.rationale: This sentence is wordy and uses a less direct construction.

answerOptions.text: In view of the fact that his car broke down, he was late.
answerOptions.rationale: This phrasing is unnecessarily formal and wordy.

questions.question: Which sentence correctly uses parallel structure?

answerOptions.text: The report was informative, well-written, and it was a help.
answerOptions.rationale: The third item in the series ('it was a help') is a clause, while the first two are adjectives. This violates parallel structure.

answerOptions.text: She likes to run, swimming, and to hike.
answerOptions.rationale: The items in the series use different verb forms ('run', 'swimming', 'to hike').

answerOptions.text: The manager's goals are to increase productivity, reduce costs, and improving team morale.
answerOptions.rationale: The third goal ('improving') is a gerund, while the first two are infinitives. The structure is not parallel.

answerOptions.text: He spent the afternoon mowing the lawn, weeding the garden, and washing the car.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. All three activities are expressed in the same gerund form (-ing), creating a parallel structure.

questions.question: Which sentence provides the most clear and effective revision of the following: 'The student who was late for class, he missed the quiz.'?

answerOptions.text: The student who was late for class, he missed the quiz.
answerOptions.rationale: The pronoun 'he' is redundant because 'The student' is already the subject.

answerOptions.text: The student who was late for class missed the quiz.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This revision removes the redundant pronoun 'he', making the sentence clear and grammatically correct.

answerOptions.text: He missed the quiz, the student who was late for class.
answerOptions.rationale: This structure is awkward and less clear.

answerOptions.text: Missing the quiz was what the student who was late for class did.
answerOptions.rationale: This version is wordy and uses passive-like construction, making it less effective.

questions.question: Which sentence uses apostrophes correctly for possessives?

answerOptions.text: The childrens' toys were scattered all over the floor.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Children' is a plural noun that does not end in 's', so its possessive form is 'children's'.

answerOptions.text: Both of my brother-in-laws' cars are in the driveway.
answerOptions.rationale: The plural of 'brother-in-law' is 'brothers-in-law'. The possessive is formed by adding 's to the end: 'brothers-in-law's'.

answerOptions.text: The class of '99 held its twenty-year reunion last summer.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. 'Its' is the correct possessive pronoun for 'class', and the apostrophe in ''99' correctly indicates the omitted century.

answerOptions.text: We visited the Jones's house last weekend.
answerOptions.rationale: To make a plural noun ending in 's' (Joneses) possessive, you just add an apostrophe at the end: 'the Joneses''. Or if referring to one person 'Mr. Jones's' would be correct.

questions.question: Which sentence is the most effective and clear?

answerOptions.text: There are many people who believe that the new policy is not a good one.
answerOptions.rationale: This sentence is wordy and uses a weak 'There are' construction.

answerOptions.text: It is widely believed by many people that the new policy is not a good one.
answerOptions.rationale: This sentence uses a passive and wordy construction.

answerOptions.text: Many people believe the new policy is ineffective.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This sentence is concise, direct, and uses a strong verb ('believe') and a more precise adjective ('ineffective').

answerOptions.text: The new policy is believed by many people to not be a good one.
answerOptions.rationale: This sentence is in the passive voice, which makes it less direct and less effective.

questions.question: Which of the following sentences is a run-on sentence?

answerOptions.text: The sun set, and the stars appeared.
answerOptions.rationale: This sentence correctly uses a comma and a coordinating conjunction to join two independent clauses.

answerOptions.text: I was tired I went to bed early.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This is a run-on sentence because two independent clauses are joined with no punctuation or conjunction.

answerOptions.text: Although the music was loud, I fell asleep.
answerOptions.rationale: This sentence correctly uses a dependent clause followed by an independent clause.

answerOptions.text: She studied for the test therefore, she felt confident.
answerOptions.rationale: This sentence correctly uses a semicolon and a conjunctive adverb.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the correct verb tense?

answerOptions.text: Tomorrow, we went to the beach.
answerOptions.rationale: The future tense is needed ('will go'), not the past tense ('went').

answerOptions.text: Right now, he is listen to the radio.
answerOptions.rationale: The correct present progressive form is 'is listening'.

answerOptions.text: Last night, they had finished the project.
answerOptions.rationale: The simple past 'finished' is sufficient here. The past perfect 'had finished' implies it was finished before another past action.

answerOptions.text: By the time the guests arrive, I will have cooked dinner.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This sentence correctly uses the future perfect tense to describe an action that will be completed before another future action.

questions.question: Which sentence has a clear pronoun reference?

answerOptions.text: After the coach and the player argued, he was suspended.
answerOptions.rationale: It is unclear who 'he' refers to—the coach or the player.

answerOptions.text: Maria told her mother that she needed to buy some milk.
answerOptions.rationale: It is ambiguous whether 'she' refers to Maria or her mother.

answerOptions.text: The report, which I left on the desk, needs to be reviewed.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The pronoun 'which' clearly refers to 'the report'.

answerOptions.text: They said on the news that it might rain tomorrow.
answerOptions.rationale: The pronoun 'They' is vague and has no clear antecedent.

questions.question: Which sentence is the most concise?

answerOptions.text: In my personal opinion, I think we should postpone the meeting.
answerOptions.rationale: 'In my opinion' and 'I think' are redundant.

answerOptions.text: The meeting was postponed by us to a later date in the future.
answerOptions.rationale: This sentence is wordy and uses the passive voice.

answerOptions.text: We should postpone the meeting.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This sentence is direct, active, and concise.

answerOptions.text: It is my belief that the postponement of the meeting is the correct course of action.
answerOptions.rationale: This phrasing is unnecessarily formal and wordy.

questions.question: Which sentence correctly uses the comparative form of an adjective?

answerOptions.text: This is the most cheapest option available.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Most' and the '-est' suffix should not be used together. The correct form is 'cheapest'.

answerOptions.text: Of the two speakers, she is the most eloquent.
answerOptions.rationale: When comparing two items, the comparative form ('more eloquent') should be used, not the superlative ('most eloquent').

answerOptions.text: He is more taller than his brother.
answerOptions.rationale: 'More' should not be used with 'taller', which is already a comparative adjective.

answerOptions.text: This book is more interesting than the last one I read.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. 'More interesting' is the correct comparative form for the adjective 'interesting'.

questions.question: Which of the following sentences contains a misplaced modifier?

answerOptions.text: Covered in mud, the little boy was happy to see his dog.
answerOptions.rationale: The modifier 'Covered in mud' could ambiguously refer to the boy or the dog, but context makes it reasonably clear.

answerOptions.text: The student returned the book to the library that was overdue.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This sentence structure incorrectly implies that the library was overdue, not the book. The modifier 'that was overdue' is misplaced.

answerOptions.text: With a sigh of relief, she finished the difficult exam.
answerOptions.rationale: The introductory phrase clearly modifies 'she'.

answerOptions.text: The car in the driveway with the flat tire belongs to my neighbor.
answerOptions.rationale: All modifiers are placed correctly and clearly refer to the nouns they describe.

questions.question: Which sentence provides the most effective revision for clarity and correctness? Original: 'The company's goal, it is to increase profits, and also improving customer satisfaction.'

answerOptions.text: The company's goal is to increase profits and to also improve customer satisfaction.
answerOptions.rationale: The structure is slightly improved but still a bit clunky with 'to also'.

answerOptions.text: The company's goal is increasing profits and to improve customer satisfaction.
answerOptions.rationale: This sentence lacks parallel structure ('increasing' and 'to improve').

answerOptions.text: The company's goal is to increase profits and improve customer satisfaction.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This revision is concise and uses parallel structure (increase/improve).

answerOptions.text: To increase profits and improving customer satisfaction are the company's goals.
answerOptions.rationale: This sentence also lacks parallel structure.

questions.question: Which sentence correctly uses subject-verb agreement with a complex subject?

answerOptions.text: The box of old photographs have been in the attic for years.
answerOptions.rationale: The subject is 'box' (singular), not 'photographs' (plural). The verb should be 'has been'.

answerOptions.text: Neither the manager nor the employees were aware of the new policy.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. When 'neither/nor' joins a singular and a plural subject, the verb agrees with the subject closer to it ('employees').

answerOptions.text: The quality of the products are not very good.
answerOptions.rationale: The subject is 'quality' (singular), so the verb should be 'is'.

answerOptions.text: Each of the committee members have one vote.
answerOptions.rationale: The subject 'Each' is singular, so the verb should be 'has'.

questions.question: Which sentence is a fragment?

answerOptions.text: She went to the store for milk.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a complete sentence with a subject and a verb.

answerOptions.text: Because he was late for the bus.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This is a dependent clause that cannot stand on its own as a complete sentence.

answerOptions.text: The game was canceled.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a complete sentence.

answerOptions.text: Wait for me at the corner.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a complete sentence (an imperative, with the subject 'you' understood).

questions.question: Which sentence correctly uses 'affect' and 'effect'?

answerOptions.text: The rain will have a negative affect on the crops.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Effect' is the correct noun in this context.

answerOptions.text: The new policy will effect many changes.
answerOptions.rationale: While 'effect' can be a verb meaning 'to bring about', the more common and appropriate verb here is 'affect'. However, the correct answer is a clearer use of the words.

answerOptions.text: The medicine did not have any noticeable side effects.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. 'Effects' is used correctly here as a plural noun.

answerOptions.text: How will this decision effect you?
answerOptions.rationale: 'Affect' is the correct verb here, meaning 'to influence'.

questions.question: Which sentence provides the best revision of the following for clarity: 'There are several reasons for the project's failure, and one of them is a lack of funding.'?

answerOptions.text: A lack of funding is one of several reasons for the project's failure.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a slight improvement, but it is still in the passive voice.

answerOptions.text: The project failed for several reasons, including a lack of funding.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This sentence is active, direct, and more concise.

answerOptions.text: Due to a lack of funding, the project failed, among other reasons.
answerOptions.rationale: This phrasing is slightly awkward and less direct.

answerOptions.text: The project's failure can be attributed to several reasons, one of which is a lack of funding.
answerOptions.rationale: This is still quite wordy and uses a passive construction.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the subjunctive mood correctly?

answerOptions.text: If I was you, I would take the job offer.
answerOptions.rationale: The subjunctive mood is required for a hypothetical situation. The correct form is 'If I were you'.

answerOptions.text: I wish I was on vacation right now.
answerOptions.rationale: The subjunctive 'were' should be used in a wishful statement: 'I wish I were'.

answerOptions.text: The manager requires that all employees are on time.
answerOptions.rationale: The subjunctive should be used after 'requires that'. The correct form is 'be on time'.

answerOptions.text: It is essential that he be present at the meeting.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The subjunctive mood ('be') is correctly used here following the phrase 'It is essential that...'.

questions.question: Which sentence is grammatically correct?

answerOptions.text: Me and my friends are going to the concert.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Me' cannot be a subject. It should be 'My friends and I'.

answerOptions.text: The dog lost its bone.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. 'Its' is the correct possessive pronoun.

answerOptions.text: There was less people than we expected.
answerOptions.rationale: Use 'fewer' for countable nouns like 'people'.

answerOptions.text: She done a great job on the presentation.
answerOptions.rationale: The correct past tense is 'did'. 'Done' is the past participle.

questions.question: Which sentence is punctuated correctly?

answerOptions.text: The movie was long, boring, and predictable.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Commas are used correctly to separate adjectives in a series.

answerOptions.text: She asked, 'what time is it'.
answerOptions.rationale: The question mark should be inside the quotation marks, and 'what' should be capitalized.

answerOptions.text: I need to buy: milk bread and eggs.
answerOptions.rationale: A colon is not necessary here.

answerOptions.text: Its a beautiful day outside.
answerOptions.rationale: It should be 'It's' to mean 'it is'.

questions.question: Which sentence provides the most clear and effective revision of 'The report was read by him.'?

answerOptions.text: The report, it was read by him.
answerOptions.rationale: This is redundant and awkward.

answerOptions.text: He read the report.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This changes the sentence from passive voice to active voice, making it more direct and clear.

answerOptions.text: Reading the report was what he did.
answerOptions.rationale: This is wordy and less direct.

answerOptions.text: It was him who read the report.
answerOptions.rationale: This is grammatically awkward 'he' would be better than 'him', but the active voice in the correct answer is best.

questions.question: Which sentence has a subject-verb agreement error?

answerOptions.text: The pack of wolves live in the nearby forest.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The subject is 'pack' (singular), so the verb should be 'lives', not 'live'.

answerOptions.text: Either the cat or the dogs are making that noise.
answerOptions.rationale: The verb 'are' correctly agrees with the closer subject, 'dogs'.

answerOptions.text: The news from the front lines is not good.
answerOptions.rationale: 'News' is a singular noun and correctly uses the singular verb 'is'.

answerOptions.text: One of my friends is coming to visit.
answerOptions.rationale: The subject 'One' is singular and correctly uses the singular verb 'is'.

questions.question: Which sentence avoids redundancy?

answerOptions.text: The two twins look exactly alike.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Twins' implies two, and 'alike' implies exactly, so 'two' and 'exactly' are redundant.

answerOptions.text: She is a new beginner at yoga.
answerOptions.rationale: A 'beginner' is by definition 'new', so 'new' is redundant.

answerOptions.text: We will repeat the presentation again for the latecomers.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Repeat' means to do again, so 'again' is redundant.

answerOptions.text: The final outcome of the experiment was unexpected.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This sentence does not contain unnecessary repetition.

questions.question: Which sentence provides the most effective revision for conciseness? 'It is absolutely essential that all employees be on time for the mandatory meeting.'

answerOptions.text: All employees must be on time for the meeting.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This revision removes the wordy phrases 'It is absolutely essential' and 'mandatory' (which is implied by 'must'), making it much more concise.

answerOptions.text: Being on time for the mandatory meeting is essential for all employees.
answerOptions.rationale: This is still quite wordy.

answerOptions.text: The mandatory meeting requires that all employees be on time.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a slight improvement, but not the most concise.

answerOptions.text: It is essential that employees attend the mandatory meeting on time.
answerOptions.rationale: This is still unnecessarily wordy.

questions.question: Which sentence correctly combines the following two ideas? 'The company's profits have declined. The company must implement a new marketing strategy.'

answerOptions.text: The company's profits have declined, it must implement a new marketing strategy.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a comma splice.

answerOptions.text: Because the company's profits have declined, it must implement a new marketing strategy.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This sentence correctly uses a subordinating conjunction to show the cause-and-effect relationship between the two ideas.

answerOptions.text: The company's profits have declined, and so, it must implement a new marketing strategy.
answerOptions.rationale: The 'and so' is a bit redundant and less formal.

answerOptions.text: The company must implement a new marketing strategy, for the reason that its profits have declined.
answerOptions.rationale: This is unnecessarily wordy.

questions.question: Which sentence is phrased in the most formal and appropriate style for a business report?

answerOptions.text: We figured out that the main problem is that we're not spending enough on ads.
answerOptions.rationale: This phrasing is too informal ('figured out', 'we're', 'ads').

answerOptions.text: The investigation revealed that the primary issue is insufficient expenditure on advertising.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This sentence uses formal language ('investigation revealed', 'primary issue', 'insufficient expenditure', 'advertising') and is appropriate for a business report.

answerOptions.text: It's pretty obvious that we just need to throw more money at advertising.
answerOptions.rationale: This is highly informal and unprofessional.

answerOptions.text: The bottom line is our advertising budget is too small to get the job done.
answerOptions.rationale: This uses informal idioms ('bottom line', 'get the job done').

questions.question: Which sentence uses capitalization correctly?

answerOptions.text: I am taking a class in spanish this semester.
answerOptions.rationale: Names of languages, like 'Spanish', should be capitalized.

answerOptions.text: We are going to visit aunt Maria in the fall.
answerOptions.rationale: Titles used as part of a name, like 'Aunt Maria', should be capitalized.

answerOptions.text: The declaration of independence was signed in 1776.
answerOptions.rationale: The names of historical documents, like 'Declaration of Independence', should be capitalized.

answerOptions.text: She works for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The names of specific government agencies are capitalized.

questions.question: Which of the following has a punctuation error?

answerOptions.text: The car, a red convertible, sped down the highway.
answerOptions.rationale: The phrase 'a red convertible' is a correctly punctuated appositive.

answerOptions.text: She packed three things: a book, a snack, and a water bottle.
answerOptions.rationale: The colon is used correctly to introduce a list.

answerOptions.text: My sister, who lives in Ohio, is a doctor.
answerOptions.rationale: The non-essential clause 'who lives in Ohio' is correctly set off by commas.

answerOptions.text: He said that, 'we should leave soon.'
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. There should not be a comma after 'that' when introducing a quote.

questions.question: Which sentence provides the most effective revision for 'Having been repaired, the mechanic returned the car to the customer.'?

answerOptions.text: The mechanic, having repaired the car, returned it to the customer.
answerOptions.rationale: This is grammatically correct, but not the most direct phrasing.

answerOptions.text: After the car was repaired, the mechanic returned it to the customer.
answerOptions.rationale: This is correct and clear.

answerOptions.text: The mechanic returned the repaired car to the customer.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This is the most concise and direct revision, embedding the idea of the repair as an adjective.

answerOptions.text: The customer's car was returned after the mechanic repaired it.
answerOptions.rationale: This uses the passive voice, which is less direct.

questions.question: Which sentence correctly combines these two ideas with the most sophisticated structure? 'The city is facing a budget crisis. Many public services may be cut.'

answerOptions.text: The city is facing a budget crisis, so many public services may be cut.
answerOptions.rationale: This is grammatically correct, but it's a simple structure.

answerOptions.text: Facing a budget crisis, the city may have to cut many public services.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This version uses an introductory participial phrase, creating a more sophisticated and concise sentence.

answerOptions.text: The city is facing a budget crisis, and many public services may be cut.
answerOptions.rationale: This is also correct but uses a simple coordinating conjunction.

answerOptions.text: Many public services may be cut because the city is facing a budget crisis.
answerOptions.rationale: This is correct but places the main point (the service cuts) at the beginning, which may be less effective depending on context.

questions.question: Which sentence is grammatically correct?

answerOptions.text: The team is getting their uniforms today.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a common usage, but 'team' is a singular noun, so 'its' is the traditionally correct pronoun. However, 'their' is widely accepted.

answerOptions.text: I did good on the test.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Good' is an adjective. The correct adverb is 'well'.

answerOptions.text: He feels bad about what happened.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. 'Bad' is the correct adjective to use after a linking verb like 'feels' to describe an emotional state.

answerOptions.text: Can I borrow your pen?
answerOptions.rationale: The correct verb for asking permission is 'May'. 'Can' refers to ability.

questions.question: Which sentence is a fragment?

answerOptions.text: The car that is parked on the corner.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This is a dependent clause that acts as a noun phrase, but it is not a complete sentence with a main verb.

answerOptions.text: Go to the store.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a complete sentence (an imperative).

answerOptions.text: It is raining.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a complete sentence.

answerOptions.text: Although it was late, we finished the project.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a complete sentence with a dependent and an independent clause.

questions.question: Which sentence correctly uses an apostrophe?

answerOptions.text: The 1990's were a great decade.
answerOptions.rationale: Apostrophes should not be used to make numbers plural. It should be '1990s'.

answerOptions.text: The dog wagged its tail.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. 'Its' is the possessive form of 'it'. 'It's' means 'it is'.

answerOptions.text: The childrens' books are on the shelf.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Children' is already plural the possessive is 'children's'.

answerOptions.text: Shes coming over later.
answerOptions.rationale: This should be 'She's' to indicate the contraction of 'She is'.

questions.question: Which sentence demonstrates correct parallel structure?

answerOptions.text: She enjoys running, to hike, and swimming.
answerOptions.rationale: The items in the list are not in the same grammatical form.

answerOptions.text: The presentation was both informative and a pleasure to watch.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Informative' is an adjective, but 'a pleasure to watch' is a noun phrase.

answerOptions.text: He is a good student, a talented athlete, and works hard.
answerOptions.rationale: The list contains two noun phrases and a verb phrase.

answerOptions.text: The instructions were clear, concise, and helpful.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. All items in the list are adjectives, creating a parallel structure.

questions.question: Which of the following sentences has a dangling modifier?

answerOptions.text: Having finished the report, Sarah submitted it to her manager.
answerOptions.rationale: The modifier 'Having finished the report' correctly modifies 'Sarah'.

answerOptions.text: To start the car, the brake pedal must be depressed.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This sentence implies that the brake pedal is trying to start the car. The person doing the action is not named.

answerOptions.text: While walking in the park, I saw a woodpecker.
answerOptions.rationale: The modifier 'While walking in the park' correctly modifies 'I'.

answerOptions.text: The book on the top shelf is the one I need.
answerOptions.rationale: The modifier 'on the top shelf' correctly modifies 'book'.

questions.question: Which sentence provides the most effective revision for clarity? Original: 'The reason for the delay is because the train had mechanical problems.'

answerOptions.text: The reason for the delay is because of mechanical problems with the train.
answerOptions.rationale: The phrase 'The reason is because' is redundant.

answerOptions.text: The delay was caused by the train having mechanical problems.
answerOptions.rationale: This is in the passive voice and is a bit wordy.

answerOptions.text: The train was delayed because of mechanical problems.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This sentence is active, direct, and concise.

answerOptions.text: The train's mechanical problems were the reason for the delay.
answerOptions.rationale: This is grammatically correct but slightly less direct than the best option.

questions.question: Which sentence correctly uses 'who' or 'whom'?

answerOptions.text: The award was given to the student whom the committee felt was most deserving.
answerOptions.rationale: In the clause 'who the committee felt was most deserving', 'who' is the subject of 'was most deserving'. The correct pronoun is 'who'.

answerOptions.text: Who should I contact for more information?
answerOptions.rationale: In this sentence, the pronoun is the object of the verb 'contact'. The correct pronoun is 'Whom'.

answerOptions.text: The person who I was telling you about just walked in.
answerOptions.rationale: In the clause 'whom I was telling you about', the pronoun is the object of 'about'. The correct pronoun is 'whom'.

answerOptions.text: She is the artist who, according to the critics, is revolutionizing the art world.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. 'Who' is the subject of the verb 'is revolutionizing'. The phrase 'according to the critics' is an interruption.

questions.question: Which sentence is the most clear, concise, and professional?

answerOptions.text: At this point in time, we should probably start to think about maybe hiring a new assistant.
answerOptions.rationale: This sentence is full of hedges and filler words ('At this point in time', 'probably', 'start to think about maybe').

answerOptions.text: It has come to my attention that the hiring of a new assistant is a course of action that we should consider.
answerOptions.rationale: This is overly formal and wordy.

answerOptions.text: We should consider hiring a new assistant.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This sentence is direct, concise, and professional.

answerOptions.text: I think that what we need to do is hire a new assistant.
answerOptions.rationale: This is wordy and less direct than the best option.

questions.question: Which sentence has a subject-verb agreement error?

answerOptions.text: The dog and the cat is sleeping.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The compound subject 'dog and cat' is plural, so the verb should be 'are', not 'is'.

answerOptions.text: Either my mom or my sisters are coming.
answerOptions.rationale: The verb 'are' correctly agrees with the closer subject, 'sisters'.

answerOptions.text: The herd of elephants is moving slowly.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Herd' is a singular collective noun, so the singular verb 'is' is correct.

answerOptions.text: Everybody wants to be successful.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Everybody' is a singular pronoun and correctly uses the singular verb 'wants'.

questions.question: Which sentence is a comma splice?

answerOptions.text: He was late, however he had a good excuse.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a comma splice. A semicolon should be used before 'however' when connecting two independent clauses.

answerOptions.text: Because the weather was bad, the game was canceled.
answerOptions.rationale: This correctly uses a comma after an introductory dependent clause.

answerOptions.text: She is a talented musician she plays the piano and the violin.
answerOptions.rationale: The semicolon is used correctly to join two related independent clauses.

answerOptions.text: I like to read, but I don't like to write.
answerOptions.rationale: The comma is used correctly before the coordinating conjunction 'but'.

questions.question: Which sentence provides the best revision for clarity? 'The car was being driven by a man with a broken headlight.'

answerOptions.text: The car with a broken headlight was being driven by a man.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a good revision that places the modifier correctly.

answerOptions.text: A man was driving a car with a broken headlight.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This sentence is in the active voice and clearly states that the car has the broken headlight, not the man. It is the most direct and clear option.

answerOptions.text: Driving the car was a man, and it had a broken headlight.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a bit clunky and less direct.

answerOptions.text: A man with a broken headlight was driving the car.
answerOptions.rationale: This phrasing ambiguously suggests the man has a broken headlight.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the subjunctive mood correctly?

answerOptions.text: I wish I was a little bit taller.
answerOptions.rationale: The subjunctive mood requires 'were' for hypothetical wishes: 'I wish I were...'.

answerOptions.text: The boss insists that every employee is on time.
answerOptions.rationale: After 'insists that', the subjunctive 'be' should be used: '...that every employee be on time'.

answerOptions.text: If I was the president, I would lower taxes.
answerOptions.rationale: For a hypothetical, counterfactual statement, the subjunctive 'were' should be used: 'If I were the president...'.

answerOptions.text: The rules require that he be notified in writing.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The subjunctive 'be' is correctly used after the phrase 'The rules require that...'.

questions.question: Which sentence is grammatically correct?

answerOptions.text: We was going to the store.
answerOptions.rationale: The plural subject 'We' requires the plural verb 'were'.

answerOptions.text: Her and I are on the same team.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Her' is an object pronoun. The correct subject pronoun is 'She'.

answerOptions.text: The dog, as well as the cats, needs to be fed.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The subject is 'dog' (singular). The phrase 'as well as the cats' is an interruption and does not make the subject plural. Therefore, the singular verb 'needs' is correct.

answerOptions.text: He don't like vegetables.
answerOptions.rationale: The correct form for the third-person singular is 'doesn't'.

questions.question: Which sentence is punctuated correctly?

answerOptions.text: I like hiking swimming and camping.
answerOptions.rationale: Commas are needed to separate items in a list.

answerOptions.text: She said, 'Let's go to the beach.'
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The comma is correctly placed before the quote, and the period is inside the quotation marks.

answerOptions.text: The cat is tired it's been a long day.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a run-on sentence. A period or semicolon is needed between 'tired' and 'it's'.

answerOptions.text: My favorite color is blue?
answerOptions.rationale: This is a statement, so it should end with a period, not a question mark.

questions.question: Which sentence provides the most clear and effective revision of 'The game was won by our team.'?

answerOptions.text: The winning of the game was done by our team.
answerOptions.rationale: This is wordy and awkward.

answerOptions.text: Our team won the game.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This changes the sentence from passive to active voice, making it more direct and powerful.

answerOptions.text: It was our team that won the game.
answerOptions.rationale: This is grammatically correct but less direct than the active voice.

answerOptions.text: The game had been won by our team.
answerOptions.rationale: This is still in the passive voice.

questions.question: Which sentence has a pronoun agreement error?

answerOptions.text: Each of the players has their own helmet.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The subject 'Each' is singular, but the pronoun 'their' is plural. The traditionally correct form is 'his or her'.

answerOptions.text: The team celebrated its victory.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Team' is a singular collective noun, and 'its' is the correct singular possessive pronoun.

answerOptions.text: Neither of the girls forgot her ticket.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Neither' is singular, and the singular pronoun 'her' correctly refers to it.

answerOptions.text: All of the students completed their assignments.
answerOptions.rationale: 'All' is plural in this context, and 'their' is the correct plural pronoun.

questions.question: Which sentence provides the best revision for clarity and conciseness? 'The fact of the matter is that the new software is not easy to use for our employees.'

answerOptions.text: The new software is not easy for our employees to use.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a good improvement, but it can be made even more concise.

answerOptions.text: Our employees find the new software difficult to use.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This sentence is in the active voice and is the most direct and concise of the options.

answerOptions.text: When it comes to the new software, our employees have difficulty using it.
answerOptions.rationale: This is wordy and less direct.

answerOptions.text: In terms of usability, the new software presents a challenge for our employees.
answerOptions.rationale: This is unnecessarily formal and wordy.

questions.question: Which sentence correctly uses a colon?

answerOptions.text: She needed three things for the recipe: flour, sugar, and butter.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. A colon is used correctly here to introduce a list after a complete independent clause.

answerOptions.text: My favorite activities are: hiking, reading, and cooking.
answerOptions.rationale: A colon should not be used to separate a verb ('are') from its objects.

answerOptions.text: He told me: that he would be late.
answerOptions.rationale: A colon should not be used to introduce a quote in this manner.

answerOptions.text: The storm was severe: but the house was not damaged.
answerOptions.rationale: A colon should not be used before a coordinating conjunction like 'but'.

questions.question: Which sentence is a run-on sentence?

answerOptions.text: The movie was long, but it was interesting.
answerOptions.rationale: This sentence is correctly joined with a comma and a coordinating conjunction.

answerOptions.text: I am tired, I want to go home.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This is a comma splice, a type of run-on sentence where two independent clauses are joined only by a comma.

answerOptions.text: Although I am tired, I will finish my work.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a complex sentence with a dependent and an independent clause, and it is punctuated correctly.

answerOptions.text: I finished my work now I can relax.
answerOptions.rationale: This sentence is correctly joined with a semicolon.

questions.question: Which sentence uses 'less' and 'fewer' correctly?

answerOptions.text: There are less people in line today.
answerOptions.rationale: 'People' is a countable noun, so 'fewer' should be used.

answerOptions.text: I have less than five dollars in my pocket.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a common usage, but 'dollars' are countable, so 'fewer' is technically correct. However, 'less than' is often used with money.

answerOptions.text: She made fewer mistakes on this test than the last one.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. 'Mistakes' is a countable noun, so 'fewer' is the correct word to use.

answerOptions.text: We need to use fewer salt in this recipe.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Salt' is a non-countable noun, so 'less' should be used.

questions.question: Which sentence provides the most effective revision for 'The decision was made by the committee to approve the project.'?

answerOptions.text: The committee's decision was to approve the project.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a slight improvement, but it is still not in the active voice.

answerOptions.text: The committee decided to approve the project.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This sentence changes the passive construction to the active voice, making it much more direct and concise.

answerOptions.text: Approval of the project was the decision made by the committee.
answerOptions.rationale: This is wordy and uses a passive-like structure.

answerOptions.text: It was decided by the committee to approve the project.
answerOptions.rationale: This is still in the passive voice and is unnecessarily wordy.

questions.question: Which sentence correctly uses a hyphenated compound modifier?

answerOptions.text: She took a last minute decision to leave.
answerOptions.rationale: When a compound modifier comes before a noun, it should usually be hyphenated: 'last-minute decision'.

answerOptions.text: She took a last-minute decision to leave.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. 'Last-minute' correctly modifies 'decision'.

answerOptions.text: She took a last, minute decision to leave.
answerOptions.rationale: A comma is incorrect here; use a hyphen to join the words as one modifier.

answerOptions.text: She took a last minute-decision to leave.
answerOptions.rationale: The hyphen is misplaced; it should connect 'last' and 'minute'.

questions.question: Which sentence avoids a dangling modifier?

answerOptions.text: Walking to the bus stop, the rain soaked my jacket.
answerOptions.rationale: This implies the rain was walking; the modifier dangles.

answerOptions.text: Walking to the bus stop, I got my jacket soaked by the rain.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The subject 'I' performs the action in the modifier.

answerOptions.text: While walking to the bus stop, the jacket was soaked by the rain.
answerOptions.rationale: The subject of 'walking' is unclear; this still dangles.

answerOptions.text: Walking to the bus stop, it rained heavily on my jacket.
answerOptions.rationale: 'It' is vague and does not fix the dangling modifier.

questions.question: Which sentence correctly uses a comma after an introductory element?

answerOptions.text: After finishing the report we met with the client.
answerOptions.rationale: A comma is needed after the introductory clause 'After finishing the report'.

answerOptions.text: After finishing the report, we met with the client.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The introductory clause is set off with a comma.

answerOptions.text: After, finishing the report we met with the client.
answerOptions.rationale: The comma is misplaced; it should follow the introductory clause.

answerOptions.text: After finishing, the report we met with the client.
answerOptions.rationale: This incorrectly splits the introductory clause and the main clause.

questions.question: Which sentence is grammatically correct?

answerOptions.text: The team, along with their coach, are on the bus.
answerOptions.rationale: The subject is 'team' (singular), so the verb should be 'is'.

answerOptions.text: He should of told me he was going to be late.
answerOptions.rationale: The correct phrasing is 'should have', not 'should of'.

answerOptions.text: Between you and me, I don't think this is a good idea.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. 'Me' is the correct object pronoun to use after the preposition 'between'.

answerOptions.text: There is many reasons why I can't go.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Reasons' is plural, so the verb should be 'are'.

questions.question: Which of the following is a complete sentence?

answerOptions.text: Although she was tired.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a dependent clause and cannot stand on its own.

answerOptions.text: Running through the park on a sunny day.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a participial phrase, not a complete sentence.

answerOptions.text: The sun is shining.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This sentence has a subject ('sun') and a verb ('is shining') and is a complete thought.

answerOptions.text: For example, the new software.
answerOptions.rationale: This is a prepositional phrase followed by a noun, not a complete sentence.

questions.question: Which sentence provides the best revision for 'The movie was boring to me.'?

answerOptions.text: I was bored by the movie.
answerOptions.rationale: This is grammatically correct and in the active voice.

answerOptions.text: The movie, I found it boring.
answerOptions.rationale: This is grammatically awkward.

answerOptions.text: I found the movie boring.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This is the most direct, concise, and active way to phrase the idea.

answerOptions.text: For me, the movie was boring.
answerOptions.rationale: This is grammatically correct, but less direct than the best option.

questions.question: Which sentence contains a comma splice?

answerOptions.text: She went to the library, she studied for hours.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This is a comma splice because two independent clauses are joined only by a comma.

answerOptions.text: I was tired, so I went to bed.
answerOptions.rationale: This correctly uses a comma and a coordinating conjunction.

answerOptions.text: Because it was raining, the game was postponed.
answerOptions.rationale: This correctly uses a comma after an introductory dependent clause.

answerOptions.text: He is a talented artist his paintings are beautiful.
answerOptions.rationale: This correctly uses a semicolon to join two related independent clauses.

questions.question: Which sentence provides the most effective revision for clarity and conciseness? 'It is my hope that I will be able to attend the conference that is being held in Boston.'

answerOptions.text: I hope to attend the conference in Boston.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. This revision is direct, active, and removes all unnecessary filler words.

answerOptions.text: It is my hope to attend the Boston conference.
answerOptions.rationale: This is still a bit wordy with 'It is my hope'.

answerOptions.text: Attending the conference in Boston is something I hope to do.
answerOptions.rationale: This is wordy and indirect.

answerOptions.text: I have a hope that I will be able to attend the conference in Boston.
answerOptions.rationale: This is very wordy.

questions.question: Which sentence correctly places the modifier? Original: 'The waiter served a steak to the customer that was cooked medium-rare.'

answerOptions.text: The waiter served a steak to the customer that was cooked medium-rare.
answerOptions.rationale: This implies the customer was cooked medium-rare.

answerOptions.text: The waiter served the customer a steak that was cooked medium-rare.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. The modifying clause 'that was cooked medium-rare' is now correctly placed next to 'steak', the word it is describing.

answerOptions.text: Cooked medium-rare, the waiter served a steak to the customer.
answerOptions.rationale: This implies the waiter was cooked medium-rare.

answerOptions.text: The waiter served a steak cooked medium-rare to the customer.
answerOptions.rationale: This is also correct and clear, but the other correct option is a very common and effective way to phrase it.

questions.question: Which sentence correctly uses a comma in a compound sentence?

answerOptions.text: We finished the project, and celebrated afterward.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. A comma before the coordinating conjunction joins two independent clauses.

answerOptions.text: We finished the project and, celebrated afterward.
answerOptions.rationale: The comma incorrectly splits the verb phrase.

answerOptions.text: We finished the project and celebrated, afterward.
answerOptions.rationale: The comma is unnecessary and interrupts the sentence.

answerOptions.text: We finished the project; and celebrated afterward.
answerOptions.rationale: A semicolon should not be followed by a coordinating conjunction here.

questions.question: Which option uses the correct pronoun case?

answerOptions.text: Her and me went to the store before class.
answerOptions.rationale: Use subject pronouns 'she and I' as the compound subject.

answerOptions.text: She and I went to the store before class.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. Subject pronouns are used as the subject of the sentence.

answerOptions.text: Her and I went to the store before class.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Her' is an object pronoun; use 'she'.

answerOptions.text: She and me went to the store before class.
answerOptions.rationale: 'Me' is an object pronoun; use 'I'.

questions.question: Which sentence maintains parallel structure?

answerOptions.text: The job requires writing reports, to lead meetings, and problem-solving.
answerOptions.rationale: The items are not in the same grammatical form.

answerOptions.text: The job requires writing reports, leading meetings, and solving problems.
answerOptions.rationale: Correct. All items use the same gerund form for parallelism.

answerOptions.text: The job requires to write reports, leading meetings, and to solve problems.
answerOptions.rationale: Mixed infinitives and gerunds break parallel structure.

answerOptions.text: The job requires to write reports, lead meetings, and solving problems.
